tweets.text: Long time ago

quoted.text:
Elon Musk on building his first startup Zip2

In 1995, when he was just 23 years old, Elon dropped out of Stanford‚Äôs PhD program in physics to start Zip2 with his brother Kimbal Musk.

Elon personally wrote the first national maps, directions, yellow pages and white pages on the Internet that summer in C with a little C++.

In this CBS interview, a 27 year old Elon describes living in a $200/month office with a leaky roof:

‚ÄúWe found that an office was actually cheaper than apartment in Silicon Valley and we got this dinky little office that had a leaky roof. It was just the nastiest place you could imagine. I lived in it too and showered at the YMCA. This lasted for about three or four months, and the reason we chose this office ‚Äî in addition to it being really cheap ‚Äî was that there was an internet service provider on the floor below. So we were able to get really cheap internet access by drilling a hole in the floor and connecting to their server directly.‚Äù

In February 1999 ‚Äî less than a year after this interview ‚Äî Compaq would purchase Zip2 for $307 million in cash.

The interviewer also asks Elon what he thinks the future of the Internet will be, to which Elon responds:

‚ÄúI think the internet is the superset of all media. It is the be all and end all of media. One will see print, broadcast, radio ‚Äî essentially all media ‚Äî folding into the internet. What the internet amounts to is it‚Äôs the first two-way communication medium that is intelligent. It allows consumers to choose what they want to see, when they want to see it.‚Äù

tweets.text:
RT @MarioNawfal: ELON: CIVILIZATIONS FREEZE WHEN RULES NEVER GET DELETED

Legislative gridlock paralyze innovation. 

Using an analogy from‚Ä¶

retweet.text:
ELON: CIVILIZATIONS FREEZE WHEN RULES NEVER GET DELETED

Legislative gridlock paralyze innovation. 

Using an analogy from Gulliver‚Äôs Travels, Elon argued that the U.S. has become a giant pinned to the ground and not by one massive chain, but by "a million little strings" of regulations that make even the simplest progress illegal. 

Thankfully for the U.S., DOGE isn't just an advisory body; it‚Äôs the "garbage collection" function required to prevent the "hardening of the arteries" of America

‚ÄúThere‚Äôs a thing that happens over time with any civilization. 

Laws and regulations just accumulate. 

If there isn‚Äôt some forcing function to clean them up, eventually everything becomes illegal. 

It‚Äôs like hardening of the arteries, or being tied down by a million little strings. 

No single string is the problem. 

It‚Äôs all of them together.

There has to be a kind of garbage collection for laws and regulations. 

Otherwise you just keep adding rules until nothing can move. 

That‚Äôs why big projects stop happening. 

It‚Äôs not that people forgot how to build. It‚Äôs that it becomes illegal six ways from Sunday to do anything.‚Äù

Source: @teslaownersSV

STRAIGHT TO THE POINT: Independent Journalism Will Dominate 2026

In 2025, our team bet big on independent journalism.

Trust in mainstream media hit new lows as independent journalism exploded on @X  

In the spirit of transparency, and as an investment in the future of independent journalism, we are releasing the ‚Äúuntold story‚Äù of my Hunter Biden reporting at CBS News.

This video, recorded in 2024, underscores everything that has gone wrong with corporate media. 

It reveals the blocks I faced as the CBS News Senior Investigative Correspondent assigned to the Hunter Biden probe, the bias and the controversy surrounding my reporting starting in October 2020.

At that time, CBS News was under different management and did not comment for our story.

tweets.text:
RT @ElonClipsX: Elon Musk: To really be intelligent, AI has to make predictions that are in line with reality.

‚ÄúIt's incredibly important‚Ä¶

retweet.text:
Elon Musk: To really be intelligent, AI has to make predictions that are in line with reality.

‚ÄúIt's incredibly important for an AI model to be grounded in reality. I have a saying, which is physics is the law and everything else is a recommendation. I'm not suggesting people break the laws made by humans, we should generally obey the laws of humans. But I've seen many people break human made laws, but I have not seen anyone break the laws of physics. 

So, for any given AI, grounding it against reality and reality, for example, as you mentioned with the car, it needs to drive safely and correctly. The humanoid robot Optimus needs to perform the task that it's being asked to perform. These are things that are very helpful for ensuring that the model is truthful and accurate because it has to adhere to the laws of physics. So I think that's actually maybe somewhat overlooked or at least not talked about enough is that to really be intelligent it's got to make predictions that are in line with reality. In other words, physics.‚Äù

Conversation with Satya Nadella, May 19, 2025

tweets.text:
RT @Teslaconomics: Tesla FSD is life‚Äôs time and money glitch.

When you‚Äôre the driver of a Tesla, you sit down, relax, and let the car hand‚Ä¶

retweet.text:
Tesla FSD is life‚Äôs time and money glitch.

When you‚Äôre the driver of a Tesla, you sit down, relax, and let the car handle 100% of the work. It takes you where you need to go while you get your time back with no stress, when normally, the car would be doing nothing and a human would be doing 100% of the work. 

Then, while you‚Äôre at home with your family, sleeping, working, or just living life being present‚Ä¶ that same Tesla will be able to go out on its own, pick people up, drop them off, and earn $ for you. 

This is what makes this technology feel like a glitch that gives you your time back and makes $ for you, all enabled by this technology that lives in every Tesla. 

For all of history, making income meant trading hours of your hard effort for $, where you gotta show up or you don‚Äôt get paid. 

FSD flips that on its head. 

Now the car will work for you, whether you‚Äôre in it or not and time stops being the limit.

Time is the one thing you NEVER get back.

And FSD is about making the most of your limited time and keeping you safe, while it works for you in the background whenever you want.

I get it now.

Reach is no longer about cable slots or front pages. It‚Äôs about access to decision makers, business leaders, and highly engaged readers in the same place, at the same time. 

That‚Äôs why independent journalism didn‚Äôt just survive the collapse of trust in corporate media.

It moved to X and took the audience with it.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs no question that X is the platform with the greatest reach. 

And when I say the greatest reach, it‚Äôs not just the numbers, but the individuals you can have contact with, whether it‚Äôs people very senior in politics or major business leaders. 

We were super thrilled when Elon Musk subscribed to our account.

That was a huge compliment. 

It‚Äôs not just the size of the audience, it‚Äôs the diversity of the audience and being able to reach a lot of different types of people. 

The powerful, the decision makers, but also everyday consumers of information. 

On X, the people following the account are far more engaged in the news. 

They‚Äôre super consumers of information. 

You can‚Äôt argue with the numbers.‚Äù
